I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the O Mon IV Combined Cycle Power Plant Project.1 
 
2.  The project will construct a 750-megawatt (MW) combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) 
power plant at the O Mon thermal power complex. The project is in O Mon district in the city of 
Can Tho, about 250 kilometers south of Ho Chi Minh City.2 The project will help Viet Nam meet 
the  fast-growing  demand  for  electricity  to  foster  socioeconomic  development  and 
industrialization in the south, particularly in the Mekong Delta. The project is part of the least-
cost Seventh Master Power Development Plan approved by the Government of Viet Nam in 
2011. 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Meeting  the  demand.  Strong  economic  growth  (about  8%  a  year  during  the  past 
decade), rapid industrialization, an expansion of business and services, coupled with rising 
household consumptions have been the causes of the electricity demand growth. Electricity 
consumption grew at an annual average of 15% per year in 2000–2009 and accelerated to 18% 
in 2010. Electricity demand is projected to continue to grow rapidly: 13% per year in 2011–2015, 
11% per year in 2015–2020, and 9% per year in 2020–2025 according to the Seventh Master 
Power Development Plan. From 1995 to 2009, household access to electricity increased from 
50% to more than 94%, and per capita electricity consumption rose during the same period from 
156 kilowatt-hours (kWh) to about 900 kWh. Rapid economic growth has helped Viet Nam 
reduce the share of the population below the poverty line from 58% in 1993 to 13% in 2009. 
 
4.  To meet this rapidly growing demand for electricity, the government plans to increase 
generating capacity by maximizing use of the country’s energy resources.  Despite construction 
of new generating capacity, power shortage still occurs in the country as electricity demand still 
outstrips supply3. To address this deficit and improve the quality and reliability of the electricity 
supply to consumers, the government plans to increase generating capacity from 18,481 MW in 
2010 to 35,000 MW in 2015 and 60,000 MW in 2020.  
 
5.  In the south, where natural gas is available, several gas-based power complexes have 
been built, including Phu My (4,000 MW), Nhon Trach (1,500 MW), and Ca Mau (1,500 MW). A 
consortium comprising Chevron and the PetroVietnam Oil and Gas Group (PVN) is developing 
Block B/52 in the Gulf of Thailand and transporting the natural gas to the O Mon power complex 
for electricity generation. The O Mon IV power plant is one of the four power plants to be 
developed at the complex to meet the growing demand for electricity in southern Viet Nam.  
 
6.  Meeting  investment  requirements.  To  build  a  sufficient  power  system  (including 
generation, transmission, and distribution), Viet Nam must mobilize about $44 billion for 2010–
2015, of which about $27 billion will be invested in new generation facilities and $17 billion in 
transmission and distribution facilities. Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN) is expected to mobilize

$32.7 billion. The balance of $11.3 billion will come from non-EVN domestic and international 
investors.  The  financing  support  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  O Mon  IV  is 
essential for EVN and the government to meet its investment requirement. 
 
7.  Public–private partnership. The private sector already plays a significant role in power 
generation.  Of  the  18,481  MW  of  installed  generating  capacity,  EVN  accounts  for  66%, 
independent power producers 24%, and BOT projects 10%. The government has adopted a 
unique public–private partnership (PPP) approach where a power complex hosts both an EVN 
power plant and a privately owned power plant. The project site and its common facilities are 
developed by EVN with public financing. ADB has provided such financing to a number of PPP 
projects, for example, the Mong Duong 1 Thermal Power Project, the Phu My 2.2, and Phu My 3 
gas-fired combined cycle power projects. This approach creates incentives for private sector in 
utilizing the common facilities provided by EVN. A similar approach is being used at the O Mon 
power complex, where EVN invests in O Mon IV and invites private investors to invest in O Mon 
II.4 ADB in helping EVN finance O Mon IV and the government in bidding out O Mon II, is 
facilitating PPP for the development of the O Mon power complex. 
 
8.  Promoting state of the art technology. ADB's assistance to the O Mon power complex 
is not limited to financing O Mon IV. ADB financed and coordinated a number of studies that 
demonstrated various gas supply—consumption scenarios and related gas pricing. The O Mon 
complex (3,600 MW) will generate electricity using gas, a cleaner fuel than coal alternative. As 
CCGT is an eligible technology for consideration under the Clean Development Mechanism of 
the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the ADB technical 
support facility assisted EVN in preparing the project design document for submission to the 
UNFCCC. This document estimated that the project can potentially save about 600,000 tons of 
carbon dioxide (CO ) per year based on a comparison of CO  emissions by the project with the 
2 2
system-average CO  emission factor.  
2
 
9.  Link to ADB strategy and sector road map. ADB's strategy in Viet Nam is to develop 
infrastructure essential for promoting economic growth and enabling private sector investments. 
ADB’s energy policy emphasizes increased access to electricity for all, and production and use 
of clean energy. The output of this project will be a power generation plant that produces less 
greenhouse  gas  emissions  and  helps  meet  electricity  demand  in  a  more  reliable  and 
environmentally benign manner. Thus it is in line with ADB’s strategy.  
 
10.  The energy sector assessment strategy and road map identified several areas for future 
development and cooperation with ADB and other development partners:5 (i) optimal use of 
domestic energy resources (natural gas, hydro, coal) to meet the country’s energy needs, 
thereby improving energy security; (ii) increase use of renewable energy, and promotion of 
energy  conservation  and  efficiency  for  energy  security;  (iii)  continue  sector  reforms  and 
restructuring  to  enable  more  competition  in  generation,  transmission  and  distribution;  (iv) 
mobilizing  cofinancing  for  meeting  investment  requirements  and  promoting  clean  energy 
technologies in the energy sector; and (v) regional cooperation. Hence, the project is also in line 
with the energy sector assessment. 
 
                                                
4  O Mon I (two 300 MW plants) is being financed by the Japan International Cooperation Agency. The first 300 MW 
simple cycle plant was completed in 2009, while bidding is ongoing for the second plant. The 750 MW O Mon II will 
be bid out for competitive tender to the private sector. ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department is assisting the 
Ministry of Industry and Trade in preparing the bidding documents and bidding of this plant. The 750 MW O Mon III 
will be developed by EVN with funding from Japan. 
5  Energy Sector Assessment Strategy and Road Map (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

3 
 11.  ADB and development partner coordination.  ADB plays a leading role in (i) physical 
infrastructure development for the generation and transmission system, (ii) promotion of energy 
efficiency  and  conservation,  (iii)  regional  power  interconnections,  (iv)  promotion  of  private 
sector, and (v) sector reforms and power market development together with other development 
partners.6 The World Bank is active in distribution network, and rural electrification, while Japan 
provides assistance to generation, transmission, and in preparing power development plans. 
Other partners have focused their assistance on policies and regulatory framework in renewable 
energy,  energy  efficiency,  environmental  protection,  and  climate  change.  ADB  and  the 
development partners regularly exchange information on their planned activities in the energy 
sector so as not to duplicate assistance but to complement each other’s efforts in the sector. 
 
12.  ADB’s sector experience. To date, ADB has provided six sovereign loans to the Viet 
Nam power sector amounting to $1,719 million, and two private sector loans for two gas-fired 
plants at Phu My, amounting to $90 million with associated guarantees of $60 million. Advisory 
technical  assistances  built  capacity  to  address  project  implementation,  safeguards,  sector 
regulations, and power sector reforms. ADB’s program of support to Viet Nam’s power sector is 
considered to be highly relevant7 to the country’s development goals as it was focused on 
priorities within the sector at the time the loans were made. Similarly, the technical assistance 
program  was  fully  supportive  of  the  program  of  sector  reforms  advocated  by  both  the 
government and development partners. With ADB assistance,8 the road map for power sector 
reform commenced in 2004 that led to the Electricity Law being promulgated in 2005 and 
establishment of Electricity Regulatory Authority in 2006. Further, in 2008 the Master Plan for 
restructuring the power sector by separating the generation, load dispatch, transmission and 
distribution functions, and establishing separate entities to perform these different functions was 
approved for implementation. ADB continues to actively engage in policy dialogue and assist 
Viet Nam in moving the sector reform program forward. 
 
13.  Lessons  learned.  Given  ADB’s  sector  experience,  lessons  learned  highlight  the 
importance of (i) ensuring a proper balance between transmission and generation investments 
in programming; (ii) securing cofinancing; (iii) advancing recruitment to avoid start-up delays; 
and  (iv)  limiting  contract  packages  to  reduce  transaction  costs.  This  project  enhances 
generation  capacity,  includes  cofinancing,  and  advanced  recruitment  of  the  project 
implementation consultant to avoid start-up delays.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact will be a more reliable supply of electricity to industrial, commercial, and 
residential consumers to enable socioeconomic development and industrialization, particularly 
in southern Viet Nam and the Mekong Delta. 
 
15.  The outcome will be adequate generating capacity of the Viet Nam power system with a 
more balanced capacity mix and sufficient system reserve margin to meet the growing electricity 
demand, particularly in southern Viet Nam and the Mekong Delta.

C.  Outputs 
16.  The outputs will be (i) a 750 MW CCGT power plant with net plant efficiency of greater 
than 55%, situated at the O Mon power complex in O Mon district in the city of Can Tho; and (ii) 
a set of common facilities to be used by the O Mon IV and O Mon III power plants including an 
access road, an administration building, a 500-kilovolt switchyard, a circulating water intake 
tower and pump station, a discharge tunnel and discharge canal, and a firefighting system.  
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
 
17.  The project is estimated to cost $793.45 million (Table 1).  
 
18.  The government has requested a loan of $309.89 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources (OCR) to help finance the project.9 The loan will have a 25-year term, including a 
grace period of five years, an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, 
the interest and other charges during construction as applicable to be capitalized in the loan, 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. The 
government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s 
LIBOR-based lending facility based on these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that 
these choices were made on its own independent decision and not made in reliance on any 
communication or advice from ADB. The government will relend the funds to EVN. EVN will 
bear the exchange rate and interest risks.

22.  Procurement. The procurement of civil works financed by ADB will be carried out in

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial  
23.  Economic analysis. The economic viability of the project was examined by comparing 
the  societal  costs  and  benefits  of  the  ―with-project‖  scenario  against  the  ―without-project‖ 
scenario. The costs to the society include investment and operating costs of the project, as well 
as environmental mitigating costs. Investment costs in turn include equipment, construction, 
consulting services, and project administration and management. The project costs take into 
account physical contingencies, but exclude price contingences and taxes and duties. 
 
24.  The economic value of electricity generated by the project is measured by using the 
costs to the society of not having this project (the so-called avoided costs). The project will 
generate 4,388 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of electricity for sale every year.11 This is the benefit in 
physical terms compared with the without-project situation.  
 
25.  The economic value of the project is a sum of the benefits resulting from (i) not having to 
use  reserve  capacity  for  full  utilization,  which  is  expensive  because  of  the  high  cost  of 
generating electricity using fuel oil; (ii) not having to run diesel generators for industrial and 
business enterprises; and (iii) not having to suffer from power blackout for small business and 
households. The benefit attributable to not having to use reserve capacity is equivalent to 
avoided costs and considered non-incremental. For industrial and commercial consumers, the 
benefits have two components: benefits to existing consumers (non-incremental) and benefits to 
new consumers (incremental). Non-incremental benefits are valued at avoided costs (e.g., not 
having  to  run  backup  generators),  whereas  incremental  benefits  are  valued  at  average 
electricity tariff (e.g., revenues). 
 
                                                
11 Corresponding to 6,000 hours full load per year. EVN confirmed this load factor based on the dispatching condition 
of the entire system (e.g., during rainy season, large hydropower plants will run at base load, leaving CCGT to 
cover mid-level load). Other CCGT power plants in operation have similar load factors.

7 
26.  A detailed analysis demonstrates that the project is economically robust under various 
sensitivity conditions. The project yields an economic internal rate of return of 27% and a net 
present value over 25 years of more than $481 million.12 
 
27.  Financial analysis. The financial analysis for the project was carried out in real terms 
using 2010 prices. The weighted average cost of capital, which represents the cost incurred by 
EVN in raising the capital necessary to implement the project, is estimated to be 2.6% (after tax 
and in real terms). The after-tax net present value (discounted at the after-tax weighted average 
cost of capital of 2.6%) is $217.3 million. The after-tax financial internal rate of return of the 
project is estimated at 5.2%, which is double the minimum required rate of 2.6%. Sensitivity 
analysis was carried out for the main input variable, which confirmed the financial viability of the 
project.13  
 
B.  Governance 
28.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government,  EVN,  and  CTTP.  The  specific  measures  introduced  to  enhance 
governance  and  minimize  procurement-related  risks  include  the  requirement  for  EVN’s 
inspectorate department to (i) closely supervise the bidding processes, bid evaluation, and 
construction; (ii) prevent interference in the bidding and evaluation process; and (iii) brief CTTP 
and the related government authorities, including the local prosecutor’s office, when an incident 
of corruption has been detected. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
29.  The project is in Can Tho province in the Mekong Delta. The project will contribute to 
economic and industrial growth, which will create jobs in various sectors and help to improve the 
quality of living in the Mekong Delta. Women will be among the beneficiaries of the increase in 
jobs. Women entrepreneurs will have access to an adequate supply of electricity, which could 
result in higher incomes and more women entrepreneurs in the Mekong Delta. In addition, the 
reliable supply of electricity will encourage the use of electrical appliances and reduce the 
drudgery of the work performed by women.  
 
D.  Safeguards 
30.  Environment.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  A.  EVN  prepared  a  full 
environmental impact assessment (EIA), which ADB approved. The EIA was disclosed publicly 
on the ADB website on 22 October 2010 to comply with the requirement in ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009) for public disclosure of 120 days.14 The EIA identified potential impacts 
caused  by  the  project  during  construction  and  operation,  and  devised  an  environmental 
management plan (EMP) that includes measures to mitigate these impacts.  
 
31.  Plant  operation  involves  the  release  of  warm  water  into  the  Hau  River  and  stack 
emissions such as particulate matters, nitrogen dioxide (NO ), and CO  into the atmosphere. 
2 2
The EIA looked at the cumulative effects of these impacts on the environment. The impacts of 
the warm water released into Hau River and the air pollution were examined for the entire O 
Mon complex. With regard to the warm water release, the EIA found an insignificant possibility

that the temperature of the discharged water at the outlet would exceed Viet Nam’s standard 
guidelines. Applying international best practice, which involves looking at the increase in water 
temperature inside the mixing zone, the thermal plume is not expected to have a significant 
impact on aquatic ecology.  
 
32.  The  EIA  carried  out  comprehensive  air  quality  modeling  to  forecast  the  potential 
cumulative  impacts  of  air  pollution.  Following  standard  international  air  quality  modeling 
practice, the EIA found that the air pollution from the O Mon power complex was not expected to 
exceed Viet Nam’s environment, health, and safety guidelines. With the addition of background 
concentrations, potential exceedance of the 1-hour NO  guidelines is predicted at 2 hours per 
2
year  from  the  power  complex;  hence,  the  air  quality  risk  is  not  considered  significant. 
Nevertheless,  the  EMP  includes  a  continuous  ambient  monitoring  program  that  will  be 
implemented to verify and validate the modeling, and to identify periods of adverse air quality 
that require additional management measures, as necessary.  
 
33.  The  comprehensive  EMP  includes  (i)  mitigation  measures  for  the  construction  and 
operation phases, (ii) a rigorous environmental monitoring and reporting plan, (iii) independent 
verification of the monitoring results, and (iv) clear delineation of responsibilities between the 
EPC contractor and CTTP. With a 15% contingency, the total EMP budget is close to $700,000. 
The costs for many of the EMP mitigation measures, such as the use of a low NO  burner and 
2
the treatment of all wastewater, are not included in the EMP budget because they are in the 
EPC package cost estimate and/or operating cost estimates. 
 
34.  Involuntary  resettlement.  The  project  is  classified  as  category  A  for  involuntary 
resettlement and category C for indigenous people. CTTP acquired the entire land area for the 
O Mon power complex before ADB loan processing. Resettlement for O Mon III, O Mon IV, the 
land area reserved for construction work, the access road (Road No. 2), and the second 
discharge channel was completed in 2006. A total of 95.5 hectares were acquired, affecting 601 
households,  including  226  that  required  relocation.  CTTP  has  paid  D110  billion  for 
compensation and resettlement. 
 
35.  As land acquisition was completed in 2006, the project team undertook due diligence of 
the resettlement process done by EVN and local authorities in 2006 as the basis for project 
appraisal. Due diligence, conducted in March 2010–September 2010, covered (i) the review of 
all project files related to affected property and compensation payments provided by  EVN; 
(ii) interviews with key stakeholders (village chiefs, O Mon resettlement committee members, 
and CTTP personnel responsible for land acquisition); and (iii) household surveys. The due 
diligence found that the resettlement process carried out by EVN in 2006 had been completed in 
a manner that generally complied with key aspects of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, such 
as eligibility, entitlement, and compensation for productive and residential lands and residential 
structures; resettlement assistance; and assistance for vulnerable households. However, some 
minor  additional  works  necessary  to  ensure  full  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement  were  also  identified.  These  additional  required  tasks  have  been  included  in  a 
corrective action plan that ADB, EVN, and CTTP have agreed upon.15  
 
36.  The  corrective  action  plan  focuses  on  (i)  confirming  that  there  are  no  outstanding 
grievances, (ii) improving assistance to vulnerable households, and (iii) providing jobs to project-
affected people. In addition, actions  were also agreed  on to comply with social protection 
requirements. These actions and their timing are described in para. 70 of the PAM. 
                                                
15 Resettlement Plan: Due Diligence Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
 
37.  Public  consultation  and  disclosure.  Public  consultation  and  disclosure  has  been 
undertaken appropriately. Public involvement in the planning and design of the O Mon power 
complex started in 2000 with the compensation and resettlement process of O Mon I and II. 
Consultation on the remaining power plants, including O Mon IV, started in 2005. In November 
2007,  the  EIA  report,  prepared  in  Vietnamese  and  approved  by  the  Ministry  of  Natural 
Resources  and  Environment,  was  disclosed  to  the  An  Thoi  and  Phuoc  Thoi  people’s 
committees  and  Vietnamese  Fatherland  Front.  Two  environmental  and  social  public 
consultations were also organized in 2007: (i) public consultation meetings 21–22 July in An 
Thoi and Phuoc Thoi wards, and (ii) a stakeholder workshop at the O Mon power complex on 14 
September.   
 
38.  A  grievance  redress  mechanism  has  been  developed  to  provide  a  systematic, 
transparent,  and  timely  process  for  receiving,  evaluating,  and  addressing  project-related 
complaints and grievances of affected people. This mechanism is open to all affected people 
regardless of the nature of their complaint and can be filed with up to three levels of authority: O 
Mon district people’s committee, Can Tho city people’s committee, and Can Tho city people’s 
court of justice.  
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
39.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.16 
 
40.  The project is part of a larger gas supply consumption chain, which consists of offshore 
gas production at Block B/52, gas transportation from Block B/52 to the O Mon power complex, 
and the use of gas for power generation. As such, the project outcome and impact depend on 
the timely and successful implementation of the upstream supply chains. A consortium led by 
Chevron has finished the front-end engineering design for the offshore production platform and 
has been determined sufficient gas for all power plants at the O Mon complex. A consortium led 
by PVN has finished the front-end engineering design for the gas pipeline and has commences 
construction of the gas pipeline.

10 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
41.  The government and EVN have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. The government and EVN have agreed with ADB on certain 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement. 
 
42.  In  addition  to  the  assurances,  the  loan  agreement  will  be  made  effective  upon  (i) 
approval of the KfW loan by the relevant approving authorities of KfW; and (ii) the duly executed 
and delivery of the subsidiary loan agreement on behalf of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
and EVN.  
 
43.  The withdrawal of loan proceeds will be subject to: (i) the KfW loan agreement being 
duly executed and delivered and all conditions precedent to its effectiveness (other than a 
condition requiring the effectiveness of the ADB loan agreement shall have been fulfilled) or 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB shall have been made for the fulfillment thereof within a 
period  of  time  satisfactory  to  ADB,  and  (ii)  the  signing  of  the  gas  supply  and  purchase 
agreement between EVN and PVN. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
44.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan of $309,890,000 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the O Mon IV 
Combined Cycle Power Plant Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, 
with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, including a 
grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially 
in accordance with those set forth in the draft  loan and project agreements 
presented to the Board; and  
(ii)  the proposal set out in para. 22 of this report to allow civil works, goods, and 
services from nonmember countries of ADB to be eligible for financing under the 
O Mon IV Combined Cycle Power Plant Project by the requisite affirmative votes 
of Directors representing not less than two-thirds of the total voting power of 
ADB’s members, pursuant to Article 14(ix) of the Agreement Establishing the 
ADB.  
 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda
